perturbation.original_text: Without prejudice to any legal or other rights or remedies of the party who asks for termination of this Agreement, any Party has the right to terminate this Agreement immediately with written notice to the other party in the event the other party materially breaches this Agreement including but not limited to the obligation under Article 3 of this Agreement and fails to cure its breach within thirty (30) days from the date it receives written notice of its breach from the non-breaching party.
perturbation.changed_text: Without prejudice to any legal or other rights or remedies of the party who asks for termination of this Agreement, any Party has the right to terminate this Agreement immediately with written notice to the other party in the event the other party materially breaches this Agreement including but not limited to the obligation under Article 3 of this Agreement and fails to cure its breach within ten (10) days from the date it receives written notice of its breach from the non-breaching party.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows a 30-day cure period for breaches. Reducing this to 10 days may be inconsistent with laws or regulations in PRC that require a reasonable cure period, potentially making the termination clause unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law of the People's Republic of China

perturbation.original_text: Party B shall pay the license fee to the account designated by Party A before December 31 each year.
perturbation.changed_text: Party B shall pay the license fee to the account designated by Party A before June 1 each year.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment deadline to June 1st each year accelerates the payment schedule significantly. While seemingly innocuous, if this change places an undue burden on Party B and disrupts normal business operations or financial planning, it could be argued as an unreasonable term under PRC contract law, especially if there's no corresponding benefit or consideration given to Party B.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law of the People's Republic of China

perturbation.original_text: The date when the notice is deemed to be duly served shall be determined as the follows: (a) a notice delivered personally is deemed duly served upon the delivery; (b) a notice sent by mail is deemed duly served the tenth (10th) day after the date when the air registered mail with postage prepaid has been sent out (as is shown on the postmark), or the fourth (4th) day after the delivery date to the internationally recognized courier service agency; and (c) a notice sent by facsimile transmission is deemed duly served upon the receipt time as is shown on the transmission confirmation of relevant documents.
perturbation.changed_text: The date when the notice is deemed to be duly served shall be determined as the follows: (a) a notice delivered personally is deemed duly served upon the delivery; (b) a notice sent by mail is deemed duly served the twentieth (20th) day after the date when the air registered mail with postage prepaid has been sent out (as is shown on the postmark), or the fourth (4th) day after the delivery date to the internationally recognized courier service agency; and (c) a notice sent by facsimile transmission is deemed duly served one week after upon the receipt time as is shown on the transmission confirmation of relevant documents.
perturbation.explanation: In mainland China, laws and regulations related to contract and civil procedure, the time for effective service may differ, and the length of time to the fax will be 1 week may not be considered a legally valid notice period.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law of the People's Republic of China & Civil Procedure Law of the People's Republic of China
